newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: US, Britain urge checks on biological weapons pact.
newsitem.headline: US, Britain urge checks on biological weapons pact.

text.p: The United States said on Tuesday that the threat posed by biological weapons was growing and 12 countries -- including Russia, China and Iraq -- were suspected of having active biological weapons systems in various stages.

John Holum, director of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, called for reaching agreement by 1998 to carry out international inspections of countries suspected of cheating on a 1972 global treaty banning biological weapons.
But any verification measures, which would also cover private laboratories, should protect the commercial secrets of pharmaceutical and biogenetic industries, according to Holum.
He spoke to a news conference after addressing a plenary session of representatives in Geneva from the 138 countries which have ratified the Convention on Biological Weapons.
Delegates are looking at how to boost compliance with the pact, under which states pledge never to develop, produce or acquire microbial or other biological agents or toxins.
"In general terms, we believe roughly a dozen countries may have an active biological weapons programme," Holum said, adding that this was twice the number suspected in the mid-1970s.
"Obviously those concerns give us strong incentives, and should give strong incentives to the entire international community, to negotiate this protocol," he added.
Holum declined to list all 12 countries, but named seven which appeared in his agency report to the U.S. Congress earlier this year: China, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Libya, Russia and Syria.
China's disarmament ambassador Sha Zukang, speaking at a seminar on Monday, said Beijing fully complied with the pact.
Holum, in a speech to delegates, criticised Iraq for failing to fully disclose the scope of its biological weapons programme to UNSCOM (United Nations Special Commission).
"Iraq's successive "full, final and complete' disclosures -- each one proving the dishonesty of its predecessors -- give good cause to treat the Iraqi programme as an active menace.
"It is essential for UNSCOM to be able to complete its work and certify that the programme has in fact been eradicated and discrepancies in information have been fully explained."
Holum praised Russian President Boris Yeltsin for having acknowledged and renounced in 1992 the offensive biological weapons programme Moscow inherited from the Soviet Union.
But the U.S. arms control official added: "The challenge to demonstrate full eradication of that programme still remains."
A special trilateral committee, composed of officials from Britain, Russia and the United States, was trying ensure that Yeltsin's orders have been carried out, according to Holum.
"There is a very widespread consensus that the time has come to complete this protocol," Holum said.
"Not everyone will sign up to the same timetable, but I think everyone understands that the absence of a compliance structure for the BWC is a serious omission.
The lack of an inspection regime for biological weapons stood out even more since the 1993 Chemical Weapons Convention and 1996 Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty were agreed, Holum said.
Britain is chairing the two-week talks, the treaty's fourth regular review conference, which began on Monday.
